sections.title: What is reported speech?
sections.content:
**Direct speech** repeats the exact words: *She said, "I am tired."*

**Reported speech** (indirect speech) reports what someone said without quotation marks. We usually change tenses, pronouns and time words:

• Direct: "I am tired." → Reported: She said (that) **she was** tired.
• Direct: "We will come." → Reported: They said (that) **they would** come.
• Direct: "I have finished." → Reported: He said (that) **he had** finished.

We use reporting verbs like **say**, **tell**, **ask**, **explain**. The word **that** after the verb is optional.

sections.title: Tense backshift
sections.content:
When the reporting verb is in the **past** (said, told, asked), we often **shift** the tense backwards:

• Present simple → Past simple: "I like it." → He said he **liked** it.
• Present continuous → Past continuous: "I am waiting." → She said she **was waiting**.
• Past simple → Past perfect: "I saw him." → He said he **had seen** him. (Or we keep past simple when the time is clear.)
• Will → Would: "I will help." → She said she **would** help.
• Can → Could: "I can swim." → He said he **could** swim.
• Must → Had to (or kept): "I must go." → She said she **had to** go.

If the situation is **still true** or **still in the future**, we sometimes keep the same tense (e.g. "The Earth is round" → He said the Earth **is** round). In exams and formal reporting we usually backshift.

sections.title: Pronouns and time/place words
sections.content:
We change pronouns to match the new speaker:

• "**I** am busy." → She said **she** was busy.
• "**My** phone is broken." → He said **his** phone was broken.
• "**We** are leaving." → They said **they** were leaving.

We often change time and place words:

• today → that day; yesterday → the day before; tomorrow → the next day / the following day
• now → then; here → there; this → that; ago → before

Example: "I saw her **yesterday**." → He said he had seen her **the day before**.

sections.title: Say vs tell
sections.content:
**Say:** say (something); say **to** someone (that) …

• She said (that) she was leaving. / She said to me (that) she was leaving.

**Tell:** tell **someone** (something). Tell always has a person object.

• She told **me** (that) she was leaving. (Not *She told (that) …*)

**Ask** is used for reported questions: He asked (me) where I lived. He asked (me) **if** I was coming.

sections.title: Reported questions and commands
sections.content:
**Reported questions** use **statement word order** (subject + verb), not question order:

• "Where **do you** live?" → He asked (me) where **I lived**.
• "What **is** the time?" → She asked what **the time was**.
• "Are you coming?" → He asked (me) **if** I was coming. (Yes/No → if or whether)

**Reported commands / requests** use **tell/ask + person + to-infinitive**:

• "Close the door." → He **told** me **to close** the door.
• "Please help me." → She **asked** me **to help** her.

sections.title: Quick summary
sections.content:
• Reported speech: report what someone said; optional **that** after say/tell.
• **Tense backshift** when the reporting verb is past: present → past, will → would, can → could.
• Change **pronouns** (I → he/she) and **time/place** (yesterday → the day before, here → there).
• **Tell** + person + (that); **say** (that) or say to someone (that).
• Reported questions: **statement order** (where I lived); Yes/No → **if/whether**.
• Commands: **tell/ask + person + to-infinitive**.

sections.title: Typical learner errors
sections.content:
• **No backshift:** Wrong: *She said she is tired.* (If reporting in the past) Right: **She said she was tired.**
• **Question word order in reported questions:** Wrong: *He asked where do I live.* Right: **He asked where I lived.** (Statement order.)
• **Tell without object:** Wrong: *She told (that) she would come.* Right: **She told me (that) she would come.** or **She said (that) she would come.**
• **Say + person without 'to':** Wrong: *She said me that …* Right: **She said to me that …** or **She told me that …**
• **Command form:** Wrong: *He said me close the door.* Right: **He told me to close the door.**

questions.question: "I am leaving tomorrow." Which reported sentence is correct?

options.a: She said she was leaving the next day.
options.b: She said she is leaving tomorrow.
options.c: She said she was leaving tomorrow.
options.d: She said she had left the next day.

questions.explanation: Backshift: am leaving → was leaving; tomorrow → the next day.

questions.question: "Where do you live?" → He asked …
questions.explanation: Reported question: statement order (where I lived) and past backshift.

questions.question: Which sentence is correct?

options.a: She told that she would come.
options.b: She told me that she would come.
options.c: She said me that she would come.
options.d: She told to me that she would come.

questions.explanation: Tell + person (tell me). Say does not take indirect object without 'to'.

questions.question: "Close the window." → She …

options.a: said me to close the window
options.b: told me to close the window
options.d: told to me close the window

questions.explanation: Reported command: tell + person + to-infinitive.

questions.question: "I have finished my work." → He said …
questions.explanation: Present perfect → past perfect in reported speech: had finished.

questions.question: "Are you coming?" → She asked me …
questions.explanation: Yes/No reported question: if + statement order (if I was coming).

questions.question: "I am tired." → She said she _____ tired.
questions.explanation: Present → past: am → was.

questions.question: "We will help." → They said they _____ help.
questions.explanation: Will → would in reported speech.

questions.question: "Where do you live?" → He asked me where I _____.
questions.explanation: Reported question: statement order; present → past.

questions.question: "I have seen the film." → She said she _____ seen the film.
questions.explanation: Present perfect → past perfect: had seen.

questions.question: "Close the door." → He _____ me to close the door.
questions.explanation: Reported command: tell + person + to-infinitive.

questions.question: "I can swim." → He said he _____ swim.
questions.explanation: Can → could in reported speech.

questions.question: "What is your name?" → She asked (me) what my name _____.
questions.explanation: Reported question: what my name was (statement order).

questions.question: "I saw her yesterday." → He said he had seen her _____.
questions.explanation: Yesterday → the day before in reported speech.

questions.question: "Are you ready?" → He asked me _____ I was ready.
questions.explanation: Yes/No reported: if or whether + statement order.

questions.question: "I must go now." → She said she _____ to go then.
questions.explanation: Must → had to; now → then.

questions.question: Wrong: 'She said she is tired.' (reporting past words) Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Backshift: is → was when reporting in the past.

questions.question: Wrong: 'He asked where do I live.' Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Reported question: statement order (where I lived).

questions.question: Wrong: 'She told that she would come.' Correct the sentence.
answers: She told me that she would come.
She said that she would come.
She told me that she would come
She said that she would come
questions.explanation: Tell needs a person: tell me. Or use said (that).

questions.question: Wrong: 'He said me to close the door.' Correct the sentence.
answers: He told me to close the door.
He told me to close the door
questions.explanation: Commands use tell + person + to-infinitive, not say.

questions.question: Wrong: 'She said she has finished.' (reporting past words) Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Present perfect → past perfect: had finished.

questions.question: Wrong: 'He asked if am I coming.' Correct the sentence.
answers: He asked if I was coming.
He asked if I was coming
questions.explanation: Yes/No reported: if + statement order (if I was coming).

questions.question: Wrong: 'She said to me that she will help.' (reporting past words) Correct the sentence.
answers: She said to me that she would help.
She told me that she would help.
She said to me that she would help
She told me that she would help
questions.explanation: Will → would when reporting in the past.

questions.question: Wrong: 'They asked what time is it.' Correct the sentence.
answers: They asked what time it was.
They asked what time it was
questions.explanation: Reported question: statement order (what time it was).
